newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP, Intel to form Internet venture.
newsitem.headline: SAP, Intel to form Internet venture.

text.p: German software group SAP AG and computer chip maker Intel Corp. plan to announce an Internet commerce joint venture on August 5, SAP said on Friday.
SAP said the goal of the venture between its U.S. unit and the world's largest chip maker was to develop a software product that supports business applications on the Internet.
The company said SAP America Inc. and Intel would release further details August 5 at 9 a.m. San Francisco time.
An SAP spokesman, when asked by Reuters, confirmed that the product would be jointly developed by SAP America and Intel. He declined to say if development had already begun.

Earlier this month, PC Week, a U.S.-based computer industry newspaper, reported that the two were about to announce a product would be the first from SAP that is separate from its core R/3 business management software.
The partners planned to "build, market and sell open- platform electronic commerce software," PC Week reported, citing industry sources.

Previously SAP has sold only software components that work with R/3, its vast flagship program used by large companies to control manufacturing, purchasing, personnel and accounting data collecte from computers throughout their organisations.
SAP only added Internet feaures to R/3 earlier this year in version 3.1, and last year was criticised by industry consultancy Forrester Research for failing to tailor R/3 for the Internet.
Another version of R/3, version 4.0, is due in the first quarter of 1998.
